awd_titl_txt: Covalent and Transition State Inhibitor Design
awd_abstract_narration:
This award funds Professor Andrew Murkin of the University at Buffalo, The State University of New York, to develop a series of compounds that may serve as specific inhibitors of an enzyme critical to metabolism in plants and bacteria, known as isocitrate lyase (ICL). One of the obstacles to inhibitor design is ensuring selective binding to ICL over other potential targets. Meeting this goal usually requires a special interaction or group of interactions between the inhibitor and the enzyme.  One strategy for accomplishing this is to introduce a part of an inhibitor that only sticks to the target if it is in just the right place for an interaction.  A second strategy is to have the inhibitor resemble what is happening during the catalyzed conversion.  This tricks the enzyme into binding to the inhibitor tightly and with great specificity.  The current research aims to develop compounds that inhibit ICL by one of these two strategies, which may prove to be a general means for inhibiting numerous enzymes. Educational development is provided to undergraduate and graduate students, and local area teachers will be trained to perform hands-on lessons that introduce enzymes to K-12 students.

This project exploits two properties of aliphatic nitro compounds that may lead to potent enzyme inhibition. The first of these is previously unknown and therefore investigated in detail. Specifically, the carbon adjacent to the nitro group can act as an electrophile for covalent reaction with a neighboring cysteine residue under certain conditions when bound to an enzyme. Kinetic, mass spectral, and X-ray crystallographic experiments are proposed to elucidate the mechanism by which this reaction occurs between a simple nitro compound and ICL. In an attempt to improve selectivity, more elaborate nitro compounds will be prepared and tested. The second property of nitro compounds that will be utilized here is the resemblance of their conjugate bases, called nitronates, to the aci enolate form of their carboxylic acid equivalents. Through the use of kinetic isotope effects and computational modeling, the transition state of ICL will be determined. Nitronate analogues of the transition state will be prepared, with the goal of obtaining strong binding with ICL.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: THE RESEARCH FOUNDATION FOR THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW YORK

por.por_cntn:
A major strategy for inhibiting enzymes is to prepare analogues that are similar in overall structure to the enzyme?s substrate but with substitutions of the various functional groups that decorate the molecule. Mimicking the overall structure ensures the inhibitor can fit within the enzyme?s active site, and the specific substitutions not only prevent the inhibitor from participating in the enzyme?s normal reaction, they also usually increase the affinity for the enzyme, thereby precluding substrate binding. The nitro group (−NO2) mimics the carboxylate group (−CO2−) found in examples of every class of biomolecule, but it is scarcely used in pharmaceutical design.

 

The primary objective of the research funded by this award was to synthesize nitro-containing analogues of isocitrate, the substrate of isocitrate lyase (ICL), an enzyme absent in humans but essential for the survival of Mycobacterium tuberculosis during latent tuberculosis infections. Due to their simple structures, most existing ICL inhibitors lack selectivity for ICL and bind off-target, resulting in toxic effects. The nitro-containing compounds designed in this project were hypothesized to improve selectivity through one of two mechanisms: (1) reaction between the nitro group and the active-site cysteine residue or (2) mimicry of the reaction?s transition state, the form of the substrate to which the enzyme has the strongest affinity. Support for the first strategy was obtained by our mechanistic work characterizing the inhibition of ICL by 3-nitropropionate, in which this deceivingly simple molecule was found not just to bind in place of its close analogue succinate, but to react irreversibly with Cys191. Because ICL requires a magnesium ion to bind isocitrate and catalyze its reaction, we incorporated the nitro group into analogues closely mimicking isocitrate that also contained a magnesium-binding functional group. The second strategy that these compounds could potentially exploit?transition state mimicry?is due to the fact that nitro groups acidify hydrogens at the immediately neighboring position, making it facile for the enzyme or buffer to convert them into their so-called nitronate forms, which very closely resemble the purported high-energy reaction intermediate and related transition state generated by ICL during catalysis. Thus, even if these nitro compounds failed to react by reaction with Cys191, they could still bind tightly to ICL. In order to assess the ability of the nitro compounds to mimic the transition state, we performed initial steps towards determining the structure of the transition state. By synthesizing substrates containing carbon and hydrogen isotopes at specific positions and measuring their relative rates of reaction in the presence of ICL, we were able to determine which parts of the substrate are manipulated by the enzyme while it converts the substrate to the transition state. Future experiments are planned to generate a computer model of the transition state, which will aid in the design of improved inhibitors. The synthesis of the nitro analogues in this project proved to be challenging, as early introduction of the nitro group tended to prevent certain subsequent manipulations. Success was ultimately reached by instead carrying the group through the majority of the synthesis as an amino group (−NH2) before oxidizing it to the nitro group in the final step(s). Preliminary testing of one of the target analogues revealed time-dependent loss of ICL activity, a phenomenon that is consistent with reaction with the enzyme as predicted. Future investigations are aimed at confirming the nature of the observed inhibition using structural and spectroscopic methods. Our demonstration that nitro groups can react in specific biological environments may encourage their use in medicinal chemistry efforts, expanding the arsenal of drug "warheads" possessing low intrinsic reactivity.

 

The broader impacts of this award aimed to inspire students of all ages to explore science, with a focus on biochemistry and enzymology. Expanding on our past efforts with a K−12 outreach program including youths from underrepresented groups, the major outreach component of this award had been planned with local middle- and high-school science teachers to create lesson plans for testing enzymes from easily obtained sources such as vegetables, but this was precluded by pandemic-related restrictions. Eight graduate students were supported by this award, and of these, four are women, two of which have graduated and are currently employed as a postdoctoral researcher and as an academic scientist. Three female international interns also contributed to the research.

 


Last Modified: 11/07/2022
Modified by: Andrew S Murkin
